revision.text: {{Cleanup|date=February 2010}} The '''Aggregat series''' (German for "Aggregate') was a set of [[ballistic missile]] designs developed in 1933–45 by a research program of [[Nazi Germany]]'s army ([[Wehrmacht]]). Its greatest success was the A4, more commonly known as the [[V-2 rocket|V-2]]. {{anchor |A1}} ==A1 (1933)== [[Image:Aggregate (3D-comparison).jpg|thumb|right|400px|Aggregat rockets compared]] The A1 was the first rocket design in the Aggregat series. It was designed in 1933 by [[Wernher von Braun]] in a [[Wehrmacht|German armed forces]] research program at [[Kummersdorf]] headed by [[Walter Dornberger]]. The A1 was the grandfather of most modern rockets. The rocket was {{convert |1.4|m|0}} long, {{convert|30.5|cm|0}} in diameter, and had a takeoff weight of {{convert|150|kg|0}}. The engine, designed by [[Arthur Rudolph]], used a pressure-fed [[rocket propellant]] system burning [[alcohol]] and [[liquid oxygen]], and produced 300 [[kilogram-force|kgf]] (660 [[pound-force|lbf]], 2.9 [[kilonewton|kN]]) of thrust for 16 seconds. The rocket was stabilized by a {{convert|40|kg|abbr=on}} [[gyroscope]] in the nose, but there was concern that this might cause problems with the [[liquid fuel]]s{{clarify|what on earth does the gyroscope have to do with the fuel?|date=April 2018}}. Although the engine had been successfully test fired, the first flight attempt blew up on the launching pad on 21 December 1933.http://weebau.com/rocket/a1.htm Since the design was thought to be unstable, no further attempts were made, and efforts moved to the A2 design.{{Sfn | Gatland | 1989 | p = 10}} {{anchor |A2}} ==A2 (1934)== [[Image:Aggregate-2 (3D-cutoff).jpg|thumb|right|400px|A-2 Rocket]] The A2 was designed in 1934 by von Braun under the program at Kummersdorf headed by [[Walter Dornberger]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2007}} At a length of {{convert|1.6|m|0}} and thrust of 3 kN from alcohol and liquid oxygen, it was in outline similar to the A1. However, in contrast to the A1, the A2 had the stabilization [[gyroscopes]] in the center of the rocket between the alcohol and oxygen tanks, which made it more stable. The rocket weighed {{convert|72|kg|0}} empty, with takeoff weight of {{convert|107|kg|0}}. Initial flight testing was done in September 1934 at Kummersdorf.{{Citation needed|date=September 2007}} Two A2s were built for a full out test, and were named after a [[Wilhelm Busch]] cartoon, ''[[Max and Moritz]]''. On December 19 and December 20, 1934, they were launched in front of the Army brass on [[Borkum]] island in the [[North Sea]]. They reached altitudes of {{convert|2.2|km|1}} and {{convert |3.5|km|1}}.{{Sfn | Gatland | 1989 | p = 10}}{{Citation | url = http://www.aggregat-2.de/geschichte.html | title = Aggregat 2 | place = [[Germany|DE]] | language = German | contribution = Raketenaggregate „A1“ und „A2“}}. {{anchor |A3}} ==A3 (1935–1937)== Development of the A3 can be traced at least to February 1935 when Major [[Ernst Ritter von Horstig]] sent General [[Karl Heinrich Emil Becker|Karl Becker]] a budget of almost half a million marks for the construction of two new test stands at Kummersdorf. Included were mobile test rigs, small locomotives, and office and storage space. The A3 plans called for a rocket with an [[inertial guidance system]] and a {{convert|1500|kg|abbr=on}} thrust engine.Neufeld, M.J. ''Von Braun: Dreamer of Space, Engineer of War''. New York: Knopf, 2007. p 75. In March 1936, Army General [[Werner von Fritsch]] witnessed a static firing of an A3 engine at Kummersdorf, and was sufficiently impressed to lend his support to the rocket program. {{sfn|Huzel|1962|p=233}}{{sfn|Neufeld|1996|p=81}} Like the earlier A1 and A2 rockets, the A3 also used a pressure-fed propellant system, and the same liquid oxygen and 75% alcohol mixture as the earlier designs. It generated its {{convert|14.7|kN|abbr=on}} for 45 seconds. It used a three-gyroscope system to deflect [[tungsten alloy]] jet vanes.{{sfn |Huzel|1962|p=236}} The design was finished and secretly patented{{clarify|what is a secret patent?|date=April 2018}} in the spring of 1936 and further modifications that made the rocket stable at supersonic velocities were finalized in the autumn.{{sfn|Neufeld|1996|pp = 84–85}} This was the first of the Aggregat rockets to be [[rocket launch|launched]] from the Peenemünde area.{{Sfn | Huzel | 1962 | p = 235}} As part of [[Operation Lighthouse (1937)|Operation Lighthouse]] the first A3 was launched on 4 December 1937, but suffered problems with both premature parachute deployment and engine failure, and crashed close to the takeoff point. The second launch on 6 December 1937 suffered similar problems.http://weebau.com/rocket/a3.htm The parachute was disabled in the third and fourth rockets launched on 8 and 11 December 1937, but these, too, experienced engine failures, though the lack of parachute drag allowed them to crash further from the launch site.{{Sfn|Neufeld|1996|pp = 102–5}} According to another source, one A3 reached a maximum downrange of {{convert|12|km|abbr=on}} and maximum altitude of {{convert|18|km|abbr=on}}.{{Sfn | Gatland | 1989 | p = 11}} With each launch a failure, von Braun and Dornberger looked for the cause. At first there was some thought of an [[electrostatics|electrostatic charge]] that prematurely set off the parachute, but this was largely disproved. Ultimately, the failures were attributed to the inadequate design of the rocket's experimental inertial guidance system and minor instabilities in the body and fin design.{{Sfn|Neufeld|1996|pp = 102–5}} After this unsuccessful series of launches, the A3 was abandoned and redesigned as the A5.{{Citation needed|date=April 2013}} In the meantime, work on the A4 continued.{{Sfn|Neufeld| 1996 |p= 105}} ===Specifications=== :''Length'': 6.74 meters (22.1 ft) :''Diameter'': 0.68 meters (2.2 ft) :''Finspan'': 0.93 meters (3.1 ft) :''Launch mass'': 748 kilograms (1650 lb) :''Fuel'': [[Ethyl alcohol|ethanol]] and [[liquid oxygen]] :''Liftoff thrust'': 14.7 kN {{anchor |A5}} ==A5 (1938–1942)== The A5 was a scaled-down test model of the A4 which replaced the former unsuccessful A3 in this role. It was flown from 1938 to 1942, and played a vital role in testing the aerodynamics and technology of the A4. Its rocket engine was identical to the A3, with a new control system and a shape similar to the A4. 25 were launched, some several times; it was fitted with a parachute recovery system and could float for up to two hours before sinking to allow recovery by boat. Variants were constructed both with no propulsion system and [[monopropellant]] engines for [[air drop]] testing. The A5 was {{convert|5.825|m|abbr=on}} long, with a diameter of {{convert|0.78|m|abbr=on}} and a takeoff weight of {{convert|900|kg|abbr=on}}, and like the A3 was fueled with alcohol with liquid oxygen as an [[oxidant]]. The first launch of the A5 took place in the summer of 1938 at [[Greifswalder Oie]] and the first successful guided flights were made in October 1939 in order to test the control systems planned for use in the A4. The A5 reached a ceiling of up to {{convert|12|km|abbr=on}}.{{Cite book | last1 = Michels | first1 = Juergen | last2 = Przybilski | first2 = Olaf | title = Peenemuende und seine Erben in Ost und West | publisher = Bernard & Graefe | year = 1997 | location = Bonn}} {{anchor |A4|V-2 rocket}} ==A4 – V-2 rocket (1942–1945)== {{Main|V-2 rocket}} The A4 was a full-sized design with a range of about 322 kilometers (200 mi), an initial peak altitude of 89 kilometers (55 mi) and a payload of about a [[tonne]]. Versions of the A4 were used in warfare. They included the first ballistic missile and the first projectile to reach [[outer space]].{{Citation | title = Peenemuende | first = Walter | last = Dornberger | publisher = Moewig | place = Berlin | year = 1985 | ISBN = 3-8118-4341-9}}. This increase in capability came from a redesign of the A3 engine, now known as the A5, by [[Walter Thiel]]. It became clearer that [[Wernher von Braun|von Braun's]] designs were turning into useful weapons, and Dornberger moved the team from the artillery testing grounds at Kummersdorf (near [[Berlin]]) to a small town, [[Peenemünde]], on the island of [[Usedom]] on Germany's [[Baltic Sea|Baltic]] coast, in order to provide more room for testing and greater secrecy. This version was reliable, and by 1941 the team had fired about 70 A5 rockets. The first A4 flew in March 1942, flying about 1.6 kilometers (1 mi) and crashing into the water. The second launch reached an altitude of 11 kilometers (7 mi) before exploding. The third rocket, launched on October 3, 1942, followed its trajectory perfectly. It landed 193 kilometers (120 mi) away, and reached a height of 83 kilometers (52 mi).{{sfn|Neufeld|1996}} The highest altitude reached during the war was {{convert|174.6|km|mi|abbr=off}} on 20 June 1944.{{sfn|Neufeld|1996}} Production started in 1943 on the rocket. The missile testing ground at Blizna was quickly located by the Polish resistance movement, the [[Armia Krajowa]], thanks to reports from local farmers. Armia Krajowa field agents even managed to obtain pieces of the fired rockets, by arriving on the scene before German patrols. In early March 1944, [[Secret Intelligence Service|British Intelligence Headquarters]] received a report of an [[Armia Krajowa]] agent (code name: ''‘Makary’'') who had covertly surveyed the Blizna [[Rail tracks|railway line]] and observed a [[Railroad car|freight car]] heavily guarded by [[Schutzstaffel|SS troops]] containing ''‘an object which, though covered by a tarpaulin, bore every resemblance to a monstrous torpedo’''.{{cite book |last=McGovern|first=James|authorlink=James "Earthquake McGoon" McGovern Jr.|title=Crossbow and Overcast|year=1964 | publisher = W. Morrow|location=New York|page=42}} Subsequently, a plan was formed to make an attempt to capture a whole unexploded [[V-2 rocket]] and transport it to Britain. Around 20 May 1944, a relatively undamaged V-2 rocket fell on the swampy bank of the [[Bug River]] near the village of Sarnaki and local Poles managed to hide it before German arrival. The rocket was then dismantled and smuggled across Poland.{{cite book |last=Wojewódzki|first=Michał|title=Akcja V-1, V-2|year=1984| location=Warsaw |language=Polish|isbn=83-211-0521-1}} In late July 1944, the [[Polish resistance movement in World War II|Polish resistance]] ([[Home Army and V1 and V2]]) secretly transported parts of the rocket out of Poland in [[Operation Most III]] (Bridge III),[[#Anatoly69|Zak, Anatoly]]: Russian Space Web: 2009 for analysis by [[List of intelligence agencies#U|British intelligence]]. ===A4-SLBM=== In late 1943 [[Deutsche Arbeitsfront]] Director, Otto Lafferenz, proposed the idea of a towable watertight container which could hold an A4 rocket. This suggestion progressed to the design of a container of 500 tons displacement to be towed behind a U-boat. Once in firing position, the containers would be trimmed to drop their aft end to a vertical position for launch. The project was dubbed ''Projekt Schwimmweste'' and the containers themselves referred to by the codename ''[[Rocket U-boat|Prüfstand XII]]''. Work on the containers was carried out by the Vulkanwerft, and a single example was completed by the end of the war, but never tested with a rocket launch.{{Cite book | last = Paterson | first = Lawrence | title = Black Flag: The Surrender of Germany's U-Boat Forces | publisher = MBI | year = 2009 | pages = 57–58 | isbn = 978-0-7603-3754-7}} {{anchor |A9|A4b}} ===A4b/A9=== In anticipation of the possibility that launch sites might be forced back into the Reich itself, von Braun and his colleagues were put under pressure to develop a longer-range version of the A4 known alternatively as A9 and A4b, the reason for the dual designation being that the A4 series had received "national priority"; the A4b designation ensured the availability of scarce resources.{{Sfn | Neufeld | 1996 | pp = 63, 93, 250, 283}} In June 1939, Kurt Patt of the [[Peenemünde#HVP Organization|Peenemünde Design Office]], proposed wings for converting rocket speed and altitude into aerodynamic [[lift (force)|lift]] and range.{{Sfn | Neufeld | 1996 | p = 92}} As the rocket encountered thicker atmosphere on its descent phase, it would execute a pullout and enter a shallow glide, trading speed for distance. Patt also proposed the ''Flossengeschoss'' (fin projectile). Both concepts were utilized by [[Walter Dornberger]] when he drafted a memo for presentation to Hitler regarding the "America rocket" on July 31, 1940.{{Sfn | Neufeld | 1996 | pp = 138, 283}} Design studies on the A9 began in 1940. In addition to its wings, the A9 would have been somewhat larger than the A4 and its engine would have produced about 30% more thrust. Following wind tunnel testing of models, the design was subsequently modified to replace the wings with fuselage [[strake (aviation)|strakes]], as the tests showed that these provided better lift at [[supersonic speed]]s and also solved the problem of [[transonic]] shift of the centre of lift. Development was suspended in 1941, but in 1944 several V-2s were modified to an approximation of the A9 configuration under the designation A4b.{{Sfn | Reuter | 2000 | pp = 90–91}} It was calculated that by fitting wings, the A4's range would be extended to {{convert|750|km|abbr =on}}, allowing targets in Britain to be attacked from launch sites within Germany itself. It was intended that following launch the curve of the A4b's trajectory would become shallower and the rocket would glide toward its target. It was anticipated that interception by enemy aircraft at the end of the glide phase would be virtually impossible as over the target the A-4b was intended to enter a near vertical dive leaving little time for interception. The A4b concept was tested by fitting swept back wings to two A4s launched from Blizna. Little development work had been carried out and the first launch on 27 December 1944 was a complete failure. The second launch attempt, on 24 January 1945, was partially successful, in that the wing broke off, but the A4b still managed to become the first winged guided missile to break the [[sound barrier]] and attain [[Mach number|Mach]] 4.{{Sfn | Reuter | 2000 | p = 87}}{{Cite book | last = Harvey | first = Brian | title = Europe's space programme: to Ariane and beyond | publisher = Springer | year = 2003 | page = 16 | isbn = 978-1-85233-722-3}} ==Variations – Planned, not constructed== ===A6=== A6 was a designation applied to a variant of the A5 test rocket which used different propellants. Some sources indicate that it was also applied to a speculative proposal for a manned [[aerial reconnaissance]] version of the A4b winged variant of the A4. This A6 was initially proposed to the German Air Ministry as an uninterceptable reconnaissance craft. It would be launched vertically by rocket, taking it to an apogee of {{convert|95|km|abbr=on}}; after re-entering the atmosphere it would enter a supersonic glide phase, when its single [[ramjet]] would be ignited. It was hoped that this would provide 15 to 20 minutes of cruise at {{convert|2900|km/h|abbr=on}} and would allow the aircraft to return to its base and make a conventional runway landing assisted by a [[drag chute]]. However, the Air Ministry had no requirement for such an aircraft and the proposal was rejected. Similar concepts (though unmanned) were produced after the war in the form of the USA's [[SM-64 Navaho]] missile and the USSR's [[Burya]], both intercontinental cruise missiles with ramjet propulsion.{{Cite web | title = A6 | publisher = Astronautix | url = http://www.astronautix.com/lvs/a6.htm | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100107181026/http://astronautix.com/lvs/a6.htm | archivedate = 2010-01-07 | df = }} ===A7=== The A7 was a winged design that was never fully constructed. It was worked on between 1940 and 1943 at Peenemünde for the [[Kriegsmarine]]. The A7 was similar in structure to the A5, but had larger tail unit fins (1.621 m²) in order to obtain greater range in gliding flight. Two unpowered models of the A7 were dropped from airplanes in order to test flight stability; no powered test was ever performed. The finished rocket should have produced a takeoff thrust of 15 kN and a takeoff weight of 1000 kg. The design had a diameter of 0.38 m and a length of 5.91 m.{{Citation needed | date =September 2007}} ===A8=== The A8 was a proposed "stretched" variant of the A4, to use storable [[rocket propellant]]s (most likely [[nitric acid]] & kerosene). The design never reached the prototype stage, but further design work was carried out after the war by a German rocket team in France as the "Super V-2". The project was eventually cancelled, but led to the French [[Véronique (rocket)|Véronique]] and [[Diamant]] rocket projects.{{Sfn | Reuter | 2000 | p = 179}} {{anchor |A9|A10}} ===A9/A10=== {{Infobox weapon |is_missile=yes |name=Aggregat 9 | image= A9 A10 (3D-cutoff).jpg | image_size = 300 |caption= |origin= |type=[[IRBM]] second stage{{Citation needed|date=September 2007}} |used_by= |manufacturer=studied by [[Peenemünde#Army Research Center Peenemünde|Army Research Center Peenemünde]] |unit_cost=none mass-manufactured |propellant= |production_date= |service=test only, not deployed |engine=A9 |engine_power= |weight=16,259 kg (35,845 pound) |length=14.18 m (46' 6¼") |height= |diameter=1.65 m (5' 5") maximum |wingspan=3.2 m (10' 6") |speed=3,400 m/s (7,600 mph) (A9/A10 two stage combination) |vehicle_range=800 km (497.1 miles) (single stage flight) |ceiling= |altitude=190 km (118.1 miles) (single stage flight) or 390 km (242.3 miles) (A9/A10 combination) |filling=1000 kg (2204 pound) payload{{Sfn | Huzel | 1981 | p = 237}} |guidance= |detonation= |launch_platform=ground launch pad or A10}} It was proposed to use an advanced version of the A9 to attack targets on the US mainland from launch sites in Europe, for which it would need to be launched atop a booster stage, the A10. Design work on the A10 began in 1940, for a projected first flight to take place in 1946. The initial design was carried out by [[Ludwig Roth]] und Graupe and was completed on 29 June 1940. [[Hermann Oberth]] worked on the design during 1941, and in December 1941 Walter Thiel proposed that the A10 use an engine composed of six bundled A4 engines, which it was thought would give a total thrust of 180 tonnes. Work on the A10 was resumed in late 1944 under the ''Projekt Amerika'' codename, and the A10's design was amended to incorporate a cluster of 6 A4 combustion chambers feeding into a single expansion nozzle. This was later altered to a massive single chamber and single nozzle. Test stands were constructed at Peenemunde for firings of the 200 tonne (440,920 lbf) thrust motor. It was considered that existing guidance systems would not be accurate enough over a distance of 5,000 km, and it was decided to make the A9 piloted. The pilot was to be guided on his terminal glide towards the target by radio beacons on U-boats and by automatic weather stations landed in [[Greenland]] and [[Labrador]]. The final design of the A10 booster was approximately {{convert|20|m|abbr=on}} in height. Powered by a {{convert|1670|kN|abbr=on}} thrust rocket burning diesel oil and nitric acid, during its 50-second burn it would have propelled its A9 second stage to a speed of about {{convert |4300|km/h|abbr=on}} and an altitude of {{convert|400|km|abbr=on}}.{{Sfn | Reuter | 2000 | pp = 91–93}} ===A11=== The A11 (''Japan Rakete'') was a design concept which would have acted as the first stage of a three-stage rocket, the other two stages being the A9 and A10. The A11 design was shown by von Braun to US officers in Garmisch-Partenkirchen; the drawing was later published in 1946 by the US Army. The A11 was shown as using six of the large single-chamber engines proposed for the A10 stage, with a modified A10 second stage nested within the A11. The design also showed the winged A9, indicating a gliding landing or bombing mission. To achieve orbit, either a new "kick stage" would have been required, or the A9 would have to have been lightened. In either case, only a payload of approximately {{convert|300|kg|abbr=on}} could have been placed in a low earth orbit.{{Sfn | Reuter | 2000 | p = 94}} ===A12=== The A12 design was a true [[Orbital spaceflight|orbital rocket]]. It was proposed as a four-stage vehicle, comprising A12, A11, A10 and A9 stages. Calculations suggested it could place as much as 10 tonnes payload in [[low Earth orbit]]. The A12 stage itself would have weighed around 3,500 tonnes fully fuelled, and would have stood {{convert|33|m|abbr=on}} high. It was to have been propelled by 50 A10 engines, fuelled by [[liquid oxygen]] and alcohol.{{Sfn | Reuter | 2000 | p = 95}} ==References== ===Citations=== {{reflist |32em}} ===Bibliography=== * revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=March 2018}} {{Anatomical terminology series}}
[[Anatomical terminology]] is used to describe microanatomical (or [[histology|histological]]) structures. This helps describe precisely the structure, layout and position of an object, and minimises ambiguity. An internationally accepted lexicon is [[Terminologia Histologica]].
==Layout== [[File:Normal gastric mucosa intermed mag.jpg|thumb|This [[Histology|Histological]] section taken from the [[gastric antrum]], showing the [[stomach]] wall. The [[lumen (anatomy)|lumen]] of the stomach is the upper empty portion, and is surrounded by a single layer of columnar cells, called ''[[simple columnar epithelium]]''.]] ===Epithelia and endothelia=== ''[[Epithelium|Epithelial]]'' cells line body surfaces, and are described according to their shape, with three principal shapes: squamous, columnar, and cuboidal. * '''Squamous epithelium''' has cells that are wider than their height (flat and scale-like). * '''Cuboidal epithelium''' has cells whose height and width are approximately the same (cube shaped). * '''Columnar epithelium''' has cells taller than they are wide (column-shaped).
''[[Endothelium]]'' refers to cells that line the interior surface of [[blood vessel]]s and [[lymphatic vessel]]s,<ref>{{DorlandsDict|three/000035470|Endothelium}}</ref> forming an interface between circulating [[blood]] or [[lymph]] in the [[lumen (anatomy)|lumen]] and the rest of the vessel wall. It is a thin layer of simple, or single-layered, [[squamous epithelial cell|squamous cells]] called '''endothelial cells'''. Endothelial cells in direct contact with blood are called vascular endothelial cells, whereas those in direct contact with lymph are known as lymphatic endothelial cells.
Epithelium can be arranged in a single layer of cells described as "simple", or more than one layer, described as "stratified". By layer, epithelium is classed as either simple epithelium, only one cell thick (unilayered) or stratified epithelium as [[stratified squamous epithelium]], [[stratified cuboidal epithelium]], and [[stratified columnar epithelium]] that are two or more cells thick (multi-layered),<ref name="vanLommel-2002-p97">van Lommel, 2002: [https://books.google.com/books?id=EvYjLNKLu9sC&pg=PA97 p. 97]</ref><ref>van Lommel, 2002: [https://books.google.com/books?id=EvYjLNKLu9sC&pg=PA94 p. 94]</ref> and both types of layering can be made up of any of the cell shapes.<ref name="marieb-p103-104">{{cite book|author=Marieb, Elaine M.|title=Human Anatomy and Physiology|edition=3rd|publisher=Benjamin/Cummings|date=1995|isbn=0-8053-4281-8|pages=103–104}}</ref> However, when taller simple columnar epithelial cells are viewed in cross section showing several nuclei appearing at different heights, they can be confused with stratified epithelia. This kind of epithelium is therefore described as [[pseudostratified columnar epithelium]].<ref>{{cite book|editor=Melfi, Rudy C.|editor2=Alley, Keith E.|title=Permar's oral embryology and microscopic anatomy: a textbook for students in dental hygiene|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|date=2000|isbn=978-0-683-30644-6|page=9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fGonan0UwhQC&pg=PA9}}</ref>
[[Transitional epithelium]] has cells that can change from squamous to cuboidal, depending on the amount of tension on the epithelium.<ref>{{cite web |last=Pratt |first=Rebecca |title=Epithelial Cells |url=http://www.anatomyone.com/a/epithelial-cells/ |work=AnatomyOne |publisher=Amirsys, Inc. |accessdate=2012-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121219035306/http://www.anatomyone.com/a/epithelial-cells/ |archivedate=2012-12-19 |df= }}</ref>
===Mucosa=== A '''mucous membrane''' or '''mucosa''' is a [[biological membrane|membrane]] that lines various cavities in the body and covers the surface of internal organs. It consists of one or more layers of [[Epithelium|epithelial cells]] overlying a layer of [[loose connective tissue]]. It is mostly of [[endoderm]]al origin and is continuous with the skin at various [[body orifice|body openings]] such as the [[eye]]s, [[ear]]s, [[Mucous membrane of nose|inside the nose]], [[Oral mucosa|inside the mouth]], [[lip]], the [[urethra]]l opening and the [[anus]]. Some mucous membranes secrete [[mucus]], a thick protective fluid. The function of the membrane is to stop [[pathogen]]s and dirt from entering the body and to prevent bodily tissues from becoming dehydrated.
===Submucosal and muscular layers=== The [[submucosa]] consists of a dense and irregular layer of connective tissue with [[blood vessel]]s, lymphatics, and nerves branching into the mucosa and muscular layer. It contains the [[submucous plexus]], and [[enteric nervous system|enteric nervous plexus]], situated on the inner surface of the muscular layer.<ref name=WHEATERS2006>{{cite book|last=Deakin|first=Barbara Young ... [et al.] ; drawings by Philip J.|title=Wheater's functional histology : a text and colour atlas|year=2006|publisher=Churchill Livingstone/Elsevier|location=[Edinburgh?]|isbn=978-0-4430-6-8508|edition=5th}}</ref>{{rp|263}}
The [[muscular layer]] (also known as the ''muscularis propria''<ref>{{cite web|title=Oral: Four layers of the G.I. tract|url=http://www.histology.leeds.ac.uk/digestive/GI_layers.php|work=The Histology Guide|publisher=University of Leeds|accessdate=4 January 2014}}</ref> ) consists of two layers of muscle, the inner and outer layer. The muscle of the inner layer is arranged in circular rings around the tract, whereas the muscle of the outer layer is arranged longitudinally. The stomach has an extra layer, an inner oblique muscular layer.<ref name=WHEATERS2006 />{{rp|263}} Between the two muscle layers are the [[myenteric plexus|myenteric]] or Auerbach's plexus. This controls peristalsis. Activity is initiated by the pacemaker cells ([[interstitial cells of Cajal]]). The gut has intrinsic peristaltic activity ([[basal electrical rhythm]]) due to its self-contained enteric nervous system. The rate can of course be modulated by the rest of the [[autonomic nervous system]].
The layers are not truly longitudinal or circular, rather the layers of muscle are helical with different pitches. The inner circular is helical with a steep pitch and the outer longitudinal is helical with a much shallower pitch.
===Serosa and adventitia=== * '''[[Serosa]]''' (if the tissue is [[intraperitoneal]]) / '''[[Adventitia]]''' (if the tissue is [[retroperitoneal]]) -- these last two tissue types differ slightly in form and function according to the part of the gastrointestinal tract they belong to.
==Position on the cell membrane== The hollow inner part of a body organ (such as the [[gastrointestinal tract]]) or tube (such as an [[artery]]) is called the ''[[lumen (anatomy)|lumen]]''. The side of a cell facing the lumen is called the ''{{wt|en|apex|apical}}'' surface; the opposite side, facing away from the lumen is the ''[[Epithelial polarity#Basolateral membranes|basolateral]]'' surface, which faces instead towards the ''[[interstitium]]'', and away from the lumen.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Histology]] [[Category:Anatomical terminology]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Galaxy | name = BDF-521 | image = | caption = | epoch = [[J2000]] | ra = {{RA|22|27|46.66}} | dec = {{DEC|-35|07|07.7}} | z = 7.008 | h_radial_v = | dist_ly = 12.9 [[Giga-|billion]] [[light-year]]s
([[Distance measures (cosmology)|light travel distance]]) | type = | mass = | appmag_v = 28 | size_v = | constellation name = [[Piscis Austrinus (constellation)|Piscis Austrinus]] | notes = | names = CFP2010 BDF 521 }} '''BDF-521''' is a remote [[galaxy]] with a redshift of z = 7.008 corresponds to a distance traveled by light to come down to [[Earth]] of 12.89 billion light years. ==See also== *[[List of the most distant astronomical objects]] *[[List of galaxies]] [[Category:Galaxies]] [[Category:Piscis Austrinus]] {{galaxy-stub}}

In computer networking, if the network is [[Bisection|bisected]] into two partitions, the '''bisection bandwidth''' of a [[network topology]] is the bandwidth available between the two partitions.<ref>{{cite book|author = John L. Hennessy and David A. Patterson|title = Computer Architecture: A Quantitative Approach|edition = Third|publisher = Morgan Kaufmann Publishers, Inc|year = 2003|isbn = 1-55860-596-7|page = 789}}</ref> Bisection should be done in such a way that the [[Bandwidth (computing)|bandwidth]] between two partitions is minimum.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Fundamentals of parallel multicore architecture|last=Solihin|first=Yan|publisher=CRC Press|year=2016|isbn=9781482211191|location=|pages=371–381|quote=|via=}}</ref> Bisection bandwidth gives the true bandwidth available in the entire system. Bisection bandwidth accounts for the bottleneck bandwidth of the entire network. Therefore bisection bandwidth represents bandwidth characteristics of the network better than any other metric.
== Bisection bandwidth calculations<ref name=":0" /> == For a [[Network topology|linear array]] with n nodes bisection bandwidth is one link bandwidth. For linear array only one link needs to be broken to bisect the network into two partitions. [[File:Bisected linear array.jpg|none|thumb|173x173px|Bisection of linear array network]]
For [[Ring network|ring]] topology with n nodes two links should be broken to bisect the network, so bisection bandwidth becomes bandwidth of two links. [[File:Bisected ring.jpg|none|thumb|178x178px|Bisection of a ring network]] For [[Tree network|tree]] topology with n nodes can be bisected at the root by breaking one link, so bisection bandwidth is one link bandwidth. [[File:Bisected tree.jpg|none|thumb|170x170px|Bisection of a tree network]]
For [[Mesh networking|Mesh]] topology with n nodes, <math>\sqrt{n}</math> links should be broken to bisect the network, so bisection bandwidth is bandwidth of <math>\sqrt{n}</math> links. [[File:Bisected mesh.jpg|none|thumb|173x173px|Bisection of a 2d mesh network]]
For [[Hypercube internetwork topology|Hyper-cube]] topology with n nodes, n/2 links should be broken to bisect the network, so bisection bandwidth is bandwidth of n/2 links. [[File:Bisected hypercube.jpg|none|thumb|Bisection of hyper-cube network]]
== Significance of bisection bandwidth == Theoretical support for the importance of this measure of network performance was developed in the PhD research of [http://www.informatik.uni-trier.de/~ley/db/indices/a-tree/t/Thomborson:Clark_D=.html Clark Thomborson (formerly Clark Thompson)].<ref>{{cite thesis|url=https://www.cs.auckland.ac.nz/~cthombor/Pubs/cmu-cs-80-140/cmu-cs-80-140scans.pdf|author=C. D. Thompson|title=A complexity theory for VLSI |publisher=Carnegie-Mellon University|year=1980|number=Technical Report CMU-CS-80-140}}</ref> Thomborson proved that important algorithms for sorting, [[Fast Fourier transform]]ation, and matrix-matrix multiplication become communication-limited—as opposed to CPU-limited or memory-limited—on computers with insufficient bisection width. [[F. Thomson Leighton]]'s PhD research<ref>{{cite thesis|author=[[F. Thomson Leighton]]|title=Complexity Issues in VLSI: Optimal layouts for the shuffle-exchange graph and other networks|publisher=MIT Press|year=1983|ISBN=0-262-12104-2|url=http://mitpress.mit.edu/books/complexity-issues-vlsi}}</ref> tightened Thomborson's loose bound <ref>{{cite conference|author=Clark Thompson|url=http://resolver.caltech.edu/CaltechCONF:20120504-143038397|title=Area-time complexity for VLSI|conference=Proc. Caltech Conf. on VLSI Systems and Computations|pages=81–88|year=1979}}</ref> on the bisection width of a computationally-important variant of the [[De Bruijn graph]] known as the shuffle-exchange graph. Based on [[Bill Dally|Bill Dally's]] analysis of latency, average case throughput, and hot-spot throughput of m-ary n-cube networks<ref name=":0" /> for various m, It can be observed that low-dimensional networks, in comparison to high-dimensional networks (e.g., binary n-cubes) with the same bisection width (e.g., [[Torus interconnect|tori]]), have reduced latency and higher hot-spot throughput.<ref>{{cite journal|author=[[Bill Dally]]|title=Performance analysis of k-ary n-cube interconnection networks|journal=IEEE Transactions on Computers|volume=39|number=6|year=1990|DOI=10.1109/12.53599}}</ref>
==References== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bisection Bandwidth}} [[Category:Information theory]] [[Category:Network management]]
{{Compu-network-stub}}

page.title: Contributors to the mathematical background for general relativity

revision.text:
This is a list of '''contributors to the mathematical background for general relativity'''. For ease of readability, the contributions (in brackets) are unlinked but can be found in the contributors' article.
{{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}}
==B== * [[Luigi Bianchi]] (Bianchi identities, Bianchi groups, differential geometry)
==C== * [[Élie Cartan]] (curvature computation, early extensions of GTR, Cartan geometries) * [[Elwin Bruno Christoffel]] (connections, tensor calculus, Riemannian geometry) * [[Clarissa-Marie Claudel]] ([http://en.scientificcommons.org/21763238 Geometry of photon surfaces])
==D== * [[Tevian Dray]] (The Geometry of General Relativity)
==E== * [[Luther P. Eisenhart]] (semi-Riemannian geometries) * [[Frank B. Estabrook]] (Wahlquist-Estabrook approach to solving PDEs; see also parent list) * [[Leonhard Euler]] (Euler-Lagrange equation, from which the [[Geodesics_in_general_relativity#Mathematical_expression|geodesic equation]] is obtained)
==G== * [[Carl Friedrich Gauss]] (curvature, theory of surfaces, intrinsic vs. extrinsic)
==K== * [[Martin Kruskal]] (inverse scattering transform; see also parent list)
==L== * [[Joseph Louis Lagrange]] (Lagrangian mechanics, Euler-Lagrange equation) * [[Tullio Levi-Civita]] (tensor calculus, Riemannian geometry; see also parent list) * [[André Lichnerowicz]] (tensor calculus, transformation groups)
==M== * [[Alexander Macfarlane]] (space analysis and ''Algebra of Physics'') * [[Jerrold E. Marsden]] (linear stability)
==N== * [[Isaac Newton]] (Newton's identities for characteristic of Einstein tensor)
==R== * [[Gregorio Ricci-Curbastro]] (Ricci tensor, differential geometry) * [[Georg Bernhard Riemann]] (Riemannian geometry, Riemann curvature tensor)
==S== * [[Richard Schoen]] ([[Yamabe problem]]; see also parent list) * [[Corrado Segre]] (Segre classification)
==W== * [[Hugo D. Wahlquist]] (Wahlquist-Estabrook algorithm; see also parent list) * [[Hermann Weyl]] (Weyl tensor, gauge theories; see also parent list) * [[Eugene P. Wigner]] (stabilizers in Lorentz group)
==See also==
* [[Contributors to differential geometry]] * [[Contributors to general relativity]]
[[Category:Physics-related lists]]

{{Infobox scientist |name = Corrie S. Moreau |image = Corrie Moreau photo by Roberto Keller-Perez.jpg |image_size = |caption = Corrie Moreau photo by Roberto Keller-Perez |birth_name = Corrie Saux |birth_date = |birth_place = [[New Orleans]], United States |death_date = |death_place = |residence = |citizenship = USA |nationality = American |ethnicity = |fields = [[Biology]]
[[Evolutionary biology]] |workplaces = [[Field Museum of Natural History]] |alma_mater = [[Harvard University]]
[[San Francisco State University]]
[[University of California, Berkeley]] |doctoral_advisor = [[E. O. Wilson]]
[[Naomi Pierce]] | thesis_title = Evolution and diversification of the ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) | thesis_url = http://gradworks.umi.com/32/65/3265194.html | thesis_year = 2007 |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |known_for = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |awards = }} '''Corrie S. Moreau''' is an [[evolutionary biologist]], and [[entomologist]] with a specialty in [[myrmecology]], the study of [[ants]]. She is currently a [[curator]] at the [[Field Museum of Natural History]] and scientific affiliate at the [[University of Chicago]]'s Committee on Evolutionary Biology.{{cite web|title=Faculty- University of Chicago Committee on Evolutionary Biology|url=http://evbio.uchicago.edu/people/faculty/}} Moreau studies the [[evolution]], [[ecology]], [[biogeography]], [[systematics]], and diversification of insects and their microbial gut-symbionts using molecular and genomic tools.{{cite web|title=Corrie Moreau Home Page|url=http://fieldmuseum.org/users/corrie-moreau|accessdate=2013-08-30}} She has also been an advocate for increasing women and diversity in the sciences.{{cite web|title=Badass Scientists, part 2: Corrie Moreau|url=https://feministfizz.wordpress.com/tag/corrie-moreau/}}{{cite web|title=Women in Science: Corrie Moreau, Evolutionary Biologist and Entomologist|url=https://www.fieldmuseum.org/science/blog/women-science-corrie-moreau-evolutionary-biologist-and-entomologist}}{{Cite web|url=http://sacnas.org/2017/04/20/sacnistas-speak-sacnistas-lead/|title=SACNISTAs Speak! SACNISTAs Lead! – SACNAS|access-date=2017-06-08}}{{Citation|last=MarchForScience Iowa|title=March for Science Iowa - Corrie Moreau Speech|date=2017-05-21|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WRrvy1H8RII&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-06-08}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/2018/07/ants-evolution-corrie-moreau-women-in-biology/}} == Education == Moreau received a PhD in biology from [[Harvard University]] (2003 – 2007) under the guidance of [[E.O. Wilson|Dr. E.O. Wilson]] and [[Naomi Pierce|Dr. Naomi E. Pierce]]. She received a MSc{{cite web|title=SF State Magazine: Connected to the Academy|url=http://www.sfsu.edu/~sfsumag/archive/spring_09/campus6.html}} from [[San Francisco State University]] and the [[California Academy of Science]]s (2000 – 2003) and a Bachelors (1996 – 2000) from [[San Francisco State University]]. == Career == Moreau and colleagues were the first to establish the origin of the ants at 140 million years ago using molecular sequence data (40 million years older than previous estimates), and that the diversification of the ants coincided with the rise of the [[flowering plants]] (angiosperms).{{cite news|title=Ancient Ants Arose 140-168 Million Years Ago: Insects Needed Flowering Plants To Flourish|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2006/04/060407144825.htm|accessdate=16 September 2013|newspaper=Science News|date=April 7, 2008}}{{cite journal|last=Moreau|first=Corrie |author2=Charles D. Bell |author3=Roger Vila |author4=S. Bruce Archibald |author5=Naomi E. Pierce |title=Phylogeny of the Ants: Diversification in the Age of Angiosperms|journal=Science|date=March 1, 2006|volume=312|issue=5770|pages=101–104|doi=10.1126/science.1124891|pmid=16601190}}{{cite news|last=Fountain|first=Henry|title=Measuring for Liftoff (That First Flight Is Crucial)|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/11/science/11obox.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1&|accessdate=16 September 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=April 11, 2006}} In addition, Moreau and Charles D. Bell showed that the tropics have been and continue to be important for the evolution of the ants.{{cite news|last=Larson|first=Lucas|title=Why the tropics are an evolutionary hotbed: Ant family tree shows tropical New World hosts fast speciation while also keeping older lineages alive|url=http://www.nature.com/news/why-the-tropics-are-an-evolutionary-hotbed-1.12846|accessdate=16 September 2013|newspaper=Nature|date=26 April 2013}}{{cite news|title=Ant Family Tree Constructed: Confirms Date of Evolutionary Origin, Underscores Importance of Neotropics|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/04/130422101252.htm|accessdate=16 September 2013|newspaper=Science News|date=22 April 2013}}{{cite journal|last=Moreau|first=Corrie|author2=Charles D. Bell|title=TESTING THE MUSEUM VERSUS CRADLE TROPICAL BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY HYPOTHESIS: PHYLOGENY, DIVERSIFICATION, AND|journal=Evolution|date=Aug 2013|volume=67|issue=8|pages=2240–2257|doi=10.1111/evo.12105|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/evo.12105/abstract|accessdate=16 September 2013}} Moreau and colleagues have demonstrated the importance of gut-associated bacteria in the evolutionary and ecological success of ants through targeted bacterial and microbiome sequencing,{{cite journal|last=Poulsen|first=Michael|author2=Panagiotis Sapountzis|title=Behind every great ant, there is a great gut|journal=Molecular Ecology|date=May 2012|volume=21|issue=9|pages=2054–2057|doi=10.1111/j.1365-294X.2012.05510.x|pmid=22509766}}{{cite journal|last=Kautz|first=Stephanie |author2=Rubin B. E. R. |author3=Russell, J. A. |author4=Moreau C. S. |title=Surveying the microbiome of ants: Comparing 454 pyrosequencing with traditional methods to uncover bacterial diversity|journal=Applied and Environmental Microbiology|date=November 2013|volume=79|issue=2|pages=525–534|doi=10.1128/AEM.03107-12|url=http://aem.highwire.org/content/79/2/525.abstract|accessdate=16 September 2013|pmid=23124239|pmc=3553759}}{{cite journal|last=Russell|first=Jacob |author2=Moreau, C. S. |author3=Goldman-Huertas, B. M. |author4=Fujiwara, M. |author5=Lohman, D. J. |author6=Pierce, N. E.|title=Bacterial gut symbionts are tightly linked with the evolution of herbivory in ants|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|date=November 2009|volume=106|pages=21236–21241|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2009/11/25/0907926106|doi=10.1073/pnas.0907926106|issue=50 |pmid=19948964 |pmc=2785723}} including showing that bacterial gut symbionts are tightly linked with the evolution of herbivory in ants. == Awards and recognition == In 2018 elected a [[Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science]]. Featured by National Geographic as a Women of Impact in 2018. In 2016 Moreau was selected as a Kavli Fellow of the [[National Academy of Sciences]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasonline.org/programs/kavli-frontiers-of-science/frontiers-alumni/alumni-directory/corrie-moreau.html|title=Corrie Moreau|first= |last= |publisher=National Academy of Sciences|accessdate=11 January 2017}} In 2015 Moreau was included in "15 Brilliant Women Bridging the Gender Gap in Science"{{Cite web|url=http://guff.com/15-brilliant-women-bridging-the-gender-gap-in-science|title=15 Brilliant Women Bridging the Gender Gap in Science|first=Alex|last=Seedman|publisher=|accessdate=11 January 2017}} and in 2014 listed as "10 Women Scientists You Should Follow on Twitter".{{Cite web|url=http://discov-her.com/en/article/10-women-scientists-you-should-follow-on-twitter|title=10 Women Scientists You Should Follow on Twitter|publisher= L’Oreal |accessdate=11 January 2017}} National Geographic Explorer{{Cite web|url=https://www.nationalgeographic.org/find-explorers/corrie-s-moreau}} – National Geographic Society 2014. Moreau was elected a Miller Fellow{{cite web|title=List of Miller Fellows, by term|url=http://millerinstitute.berkeley.edu/all.php?nav=44#2007|year=2007}} of the [[Miller Institute for Basic Research in Science|Miller Institute]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] (2007 – 2008). She received two [http://isites.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k1985&tabgroupid=icb.tabgroup142764 "Excellence and Distinction in Teaching Awards"] from [[Harvard University| Harvard University’s]] Derek Bok Center for Teaching and Learning (2004 & 2006). Moreau was featured in Chapter 13 of [[E.O. Wilson|Dr. Edward O. Wilson’s]] 2013 book “Letters to a Young Scientist.” {{cite book|last=Wilson|first=Edward O|title=Letters to a Young Scientist|year=2013|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company Ltd.|isbn=0871407000|page=Ch.13 pp.143–147}}{{cite journal|last=Simberloff|first=Daniel|title=The Passion Principle|journal=PLOS Biology|year=2013|volume=11|issue=8|doi=10.1371/journal.pbio.1001629|url=http://www.plosbiology.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pbio.1001629|pages=e1001629}} Wilson writes “There was no bravado in Corrie, no trace of overweening pride, no pretension.” Wilson goes on to state “The story of Corrie Saux Moreau’s ambitious undertaking is one I feel especially important to bring to you. It suggest that courage in science born of self-confidence (without arrogance!), a willingness to take a risk but with resilience, a lack of fear of authority, a set of mind that prepares you to take a new direction if thwarted, are of great value – win or lose." == Personal life == Moreau was born in New Orleans, Louisiana. She was the subject of a museum exhibit{{cite web|title=The Romance of Ants Exhibit at The Field Museum|url=http://fieldmuseum.org/happening/exhibits/romance-ants}} and [[graphic novel]],{{cite web|title=The Romance of Ants|url=http://api.ning.com/files/BexZ1ADOCOibTdhHfDhEnEL4ESgDmsMP8n9JmRtv-pEHe4YvD8oPjtaJ3Au8InyIFWASyRSt*iPe-PpBhuhauekLAJ76BxZ9/AntsComicbook.pdf}}{{cite journal|title=Serious Science, Comic-Book Style: A myrmecological comic brings entomologist Corrie Moreau's journey to life|journal=American Scientist|date=May–June 2011|volume=99|issue=3|page=244|doi=10.1511/2011.90.244|url=http://www.americanscientist.org/issues/pub/serious-science-comic-book-style|last1=Clabby|first1=Catherine}} [http://www.moreaulab.org//the-romance-of-ants/ "The Romance of Ants" ]. == Selected publications == * {{cite journal | last1 = Moreau | first1 = C. S. | last2 = Bell | first2 = C. D. | last3 = Vila | first3 = R. | last4 = Archibald | first4 = S. B. | last5 = Pierce | first5 = N. P. | year = 2006 | title = Phylogeny of the ants: Diversification in the age of angiosperms | url = | journal = Science | volume = 312 | issue = 5770| pages = 101–104 | doi=10.1126/science.1124891 | pmid=16601190}} * Russell, J. A., Moreau, C. S., Goldman-Huertas, B., Fujiwara, M., Lohman, D. J. & Pierce, N. E. (2009). Bacterial gut symbionts are tightly linked with the evolution of herbivory in ants. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, USA. 106(50): 21236-21241. * {{cite journal | last1 = Rubin | first1 = B. E. R. | last2 = Ree | first2 = R. H. | last3 = Moreau | first3 = C. S. | year = 2012 | title = Inferring phylogenies from RAD sequence data | url = | journal = PLOS ONE | volume = 7 | issue = 4| page = e33394 | doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0033394}} * {{cite journal | last1 = Moreau | first1 = C. S. | last2 = Bell | first2 = C. D. | year = 2013 | title = Testing the museum versus cradle biological diversity hypothesis: Phylogeny, diversification, and ancestral biogeographic range evolution of the ants | url = | journal = Evolution | volume = 67 | issue = 8| pages = 2240–2257 | doi=10.1111/evo.12105}} * {{cite journal | last1 = Rubin | first1 = B. E. R. | last2 = Moreau | first2 = C. S. | year = 2016 | title = Comparative genomics reveals convergent rates of evolution in ant-plant mutualisms | url = | journal = Nature Communications | volume = 7 | issue = | page = 12679 | doi=10.1038/ncomms12679}} * {{cite journal | last1 = Nelsen | first1 = M. P. | last2 = Ree | first2 = R. H. | last3 = Moreau | first3 = C. S | year = 2018 | title = Ant-plant interactions evolved through increasing interdependence | url = | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, USA | volume = 115 | issue = 48 | page = 12253-12258 | doi=10.1073/pnas.1719794115}} == See also == * [http://fieldmuseum.org/ Field Museum of Natural History] * [[Myrmecology]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.moreaulab.org/ The Moreau Lab] * [https://twitter.com/CorrieMoreau Corrie Moreau's Twitter] * [https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=corrie+moreau&oq=corrie+moreau Video Interviews with Corrie Moreau] on YouTube * [https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=kV2aLd8AAAAJ&hl=en Google Scholar List of Articles for Corrie Moreau] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Moreau, Corrie}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Evolutionary biologists]] [[Category:Entomologists]] [[Category:American entomologists]] [[Category:Myrmecologists]] [[Category:Women scientists]] [[Category:Women biologists]] [[Category:Women evolutionary biologists]] [[Category:Women entomologists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from New Orleans]] [[Category:San Francisco State University alumni]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley fellows]]

revision.comment: /* Alarms */ Removed Smoke alarm section, as it being on/off does not influence the measured system, therefore deadband or hysteresis does not apply to this example.
revision.text:
{{No footnotes|date=January 2013}} [[File:Deadband.svg|thumb|Deadband is the period of dead-state of a system.]] A '''deadband''' (sometimes called a '''neutral zone''' or '''dead zone''') is a band of input values in the [[domain of a function|domain]] of a [[transfer function]] in a [[control system]] or signal processing system where the output is zero (the output is 'dead' - no action occurs). Deadband regions can be used in control systems such as [[servoamplifier]]s to prevent [[oscillation]] or repeated activation-deactivation cycles (called 'hunting' in [[proportional control]] systems). A form of deadband that occurs in mechanical systems, [[simple machine#compound machines|compound machines]] such as [[gear train]]s is [[backlash (engineering)|backlash]].
[[File:Deadband plot.svg|thumb|Input and output of the deadband operator.]]
==Voltage regulators== In some power substations there are [[voltage regulator|regulators]] that keep the [[voltage]] within certain predetermined limits, but there is a range of voltage in-between during which no changes are made, such as between 112 and 118 volts ('''deadband''' is 6 volts here), or 215 to 225 volts ('''deadband''' is 10 volts here).
==Backlash== {{see|Backlash (engineering)}} [[File:Backlash.svg|thumb|[[Backlash (engineering)|Backlash]] is a mechanical form of deadband.]] Gear teeth with slop (''[[backlash (engineering)|backlash]]'') exhibit deadband. There is no drive from the input to the output shaft in either direction while the teeth are not meshed. [[Leadscrews]] generally also have backlash and hence a deadband, which must be taken into account when making position adjustments, especially with [[CNC]] systems. If mechanical backlash eliminators are not available, the control can compensate for backlash by adding the deadband value to the position vector whenever direction is reversed.
==Hysteresis vs. deadband== Deadband is different from [[hysteresis]]. With hysteresis there is no dead zone, and so the output is always in one direction or another.{{clarify|date=January 2013}} Devices with hysteresis have memory, in that previous system states dictate future states.{{clarify|date=January 2013}} Examples of devices with hysteresis are single-mode thermostats and smoke alarms.
===Thermostats=== Simple (single mode) [[thermostat]]s exhibit hysteresis. For example, the furnace in the basement of a house is adjusted automatically by the thermostat to be switched on as soon as the temperature at the thermostat falls to 18 °C and the furnace is switched off by the thermostat as soon as the temperature at the thermostat reaches 22 °C. There is no temperature at which the house is not being heated or allowed to cool (furnace on or off).
A thermostat which sets a single temperature and automatically controls both heating and cooling systems without a mode change exhibits a deadband range around the target temperature. The low end of the deadband is just above the temperature where the heating system turns on. The high end of the deadband is just below the temperature where the air-conditioning system starts.
==See also== *[[Schmitt trigger]]
==References== *Johnson, Curtis D. "Process Control Instrumentation Technology", Prentice Hall (2002, 7th ed.) *{{cite web|title=Dead Band Plus Hysteresis Estimation with ValveLink Diagnostics|url=http://www.documentation.emersonprocess.com/groups/public/documents/bulletins/d103549x012.pdf|work=Product Bulletin|publisher=Fisher Controls International|accessdate=18 January 2013|date=October 2012}} *{{cite book|last=Murty|first=D.V.S.|title=Transducers & Instrumentation|year=2009|publisher=Prentice-Hall of India|location=New Delhi|isbn=978-8120335691|pages=15–16|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g87Zv-5onFoC&pg=PA15&lpg=PA15&source=bl&ots=lZvJ24Obik&sig=Ohgowq-z9jminYt9VrftDTeLtbY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=bdL5UMfGI4fY0QX6roC4BA&ved=0CEIQ6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q&f=false|edition=2nd|accessdate=18 January 2013}} *{{cite web|last=Postlethwaite|first=Bruce|title=On-Off Control|url=http://www.online-courses.vissim.us/Strathclyde/onoff_control.htm|work=Introduction to Process Control|publisher=Department of Chemical and Process Engineering, University of Strathclyde|accessdate=18 January 2013}}

{{Orphan|date=September 2018}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=January 2018}} Dr '''Denis Coulthard Graham''' [[FRSE]] FRSC FIB FRSA (1929-2002) was a British biological chemist. He specialised in plant diseases and their treatment.
==Life==
He was born in [[Carlisle, Cumbria|Carlisle]] in December 1929.
He went to [[Durham University]] graduating BSc. He then undertook postgraduate studies at [[Edinburgh University]] gaining a doctorate (PhD). He rose to be Director of Agricultural Scientific Services in the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries within the [[Scottish Office]]. Edinburgh University granted him a second, honorary doctorate (DSc) whilst in this role.<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf}}</ref>
From the 1970s he lived in Caiystone Gardens in southern Edinburgh.<ref>http://www.rootschat.com/forum/index.php?topic=446296.0</ref> In 1975 he was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. His proposers were [[Mary Noble]], .<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf}}</ref>
He died in [[Edinburgh]] on 12 October 2002.
==Family==
In 1968 he married Elizabeth (Betty) Fraser, a New Zealander. They had no children.
==Publications==
*''Chemical Control of Certain Fungal Diseases of Potato Tubers'' (1982)

{{lowercase title}}
'''eCybermission''' (stylized as '''eCYBERMISSION''') is a [[U.S. Army]]-sponsored online educational [[science fair]] for students in grades 6-9 in the United States or at US Army schools across the world.<ref>{{cite news|last=Neal|first=Dennis|title=Students fly 7,500 miles to compete in Army science competition|url=http://www.army.mil/article/83179/Students_fly_7_500_miles_to_compete_in_Army_science_competition/|accessdate=13 July 2012|newspaper=ARMY.MIL - The Official Homepage of the United States Army}}</ref> The contest is conducted entirely online—groups of 3-4 students submit "Mission Folders", which contain detailed information about their projects choosing either Scientific Inquiry or the Engineering Design Process.
The competition selects winners on state, regional, and finally national levels for each grade level. All regional winners receive a one-week trip to the Washington, DC area to attend the National Judging and Educational Event (NJ&EE). Students can win up to $9,000 in savings bonds (maturity value).<ref name=factsheet>{{cite web|title=eCyberMission Fact Sheet 2011-2012|url=https://www.ecybermission.com/public/NewsMedia/eCM%20Fact%20Sheet%20FINAL.pdf|publisher=US Army Research, Development and Engineering Command|accessdate=13 July 2012}}</ref> The NJ&EE event includes many opportunities to meet others, physical training, various workshops and panels, as well as the STEM Challenge, which is a day working with scientists and engineers from different sectors of [[RDECOM]], the department of the Army that oversees the events.
eCYBERMISSION is part of the Army Educational Outreach Program (AEOP).
The competition is administered by the [[National Science Teachers Association|National Science Teachers Association (NSTA)]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://ecybermission.com eCYBERMISSION Official Website] * [http://www.army.mil/rdecom RDECOM Official Website] * [http://www.usaeop.com US AEOP website]

{| class="wikitable" style="float: right;" ! Values of ''m''<sub>e</sub> ! Units |- | {{val|9.10938356|(11)|e=−31}} || [[kilogram|kg]] |- | {{val|5.485799090|(16)|e=−4}} || [[atomic mass unit|u]] |- | {{val|8.18710565|(10)|e=−14}} || [[Joule|J/c<sup>2</sup>]] |- | {{val|0.5109989461|(13)|}} || [[Electronvolt|MeV/c<sup>2</sup>]] |- ! Values of the energy of ''m''<sub>e</sub> ! Units |- | {{val|8.18710565|(10)|e=−14}} || [[Joule|J]] |- | {{val|0.5109989461|(13)}} || [[Electronvolt|MeV]] |- |}
The '''electron rest mass''' (symbol: {{math|'''''m''<sub>e</sub>'''}}) is the [[Mass in special relativity|mass]] of a stationary [[electron]]. It is one of the fundamental [[Physical constant|constants]] of [[physics]] and is also very important in [[chemistry]] because of its relation{{dubious|date=June 2018}} to the [[Avogadro constant]]. It has a value of about {{val|9.109|e=−31}} [[kilogram]]s or about {{val|5.486|e=−4}} [[atomic mass unit]]s, [[Mass–energy equivalence|equivalent]] to an [[energy]] of about {{val|8.187|e=−14}} [[joule]]s or about 0.5110 [[Electronvolt|MeV]].<ref name="CODATA">[[CODATA 2014]]</ref>
== Terminology == The term "rest mass" is used because according to [[special relativity]] the mass of an object is increased in a frame of reference that is moving relative to that object. Most practical measurements are carried out on moving electrons. If the electron is moving at a [[Relativistic speed|relativistic velocity]], the result must therefore be corrected to obtain the rest mass. This correction is only substantial for electrons accelerated by voltages of well over 100 [[Volt|kV]].
== Determination == Since the electron mass determines a number of observed effects in atomic physics, there are potentially many ways to determine its mass from an experiment, if the values of other physical constants are already considered known.
Historically, the mass of the electron was determined directly from combining two measurements. The [[mass-to-charge ratio]] of the electron was first estimated by [[Arthur Schuster]] in 1890 by measuring the deflection of "cathode rays" due to a known magnetic field in a [[cathode ray tube]]. This was before it was even known what cathode rays actually were! It was seven years later that [[J. J. Thomson]] showed that cathode rays consist of streams of particles, to be called electrons, and made more precise measurements of their mass-to-charge ratio again using a cathode ray tube.
The second measurement was of the [[Electric charge|charge]] of the electron. This was determined with a precision of better than 1% by [[Robert A. Millikan]] in his famous [[oil drop experiment]] in 1909. Together with the mass-to-charge ratio, the electron mass was thereby determined with reasonable precision. The value of mass that was found for the electron was initially met with surprise by physicists, since it was so small (less than .1%) compared to the known mass of a hydrogen atom.
The electron rest mass can be calculated from the [[Rydberg constant]] ''R''<sub>∞</sub> and the [[fine structure constant]] ''α'' obtained through spectroscopic measurements. Using the definition of the Rydberg constant:
:<math>R_{\infty} = \frac{m_{\rm e}c\alpha^2}{2h} </math>,
thus
:<math>m_{\rm e} = \frac{2R_{\infty}h}{c\alpha^2}</math>
where ''c'' is the speed of light and ''h'' is the [[Planck constant]].<ref name="CODATA" /> The relative uncertainty, 5{{e|−8}} in the 2006 [[Committee on Data for Science and Technology | CODATA]] recommended value,<ref name="NIST">{{citation | title = The NIST reference on Constants, Units, and Uncertainty | url = http://physics.nist.gov/cuu/index.html | publisher = [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]]}}</ref> is due entirely to the uncertainty in the value of the Planck constant.
The electron relative atomic mass can be measured directly in a [[Penning trap]]. It can also be inferred from the spectra of [[antiprotonic helium]] atoms ([[helium]] atoms where one of the electrons has been replaced by an [[antiproton]]) or from measurements of the electron [[g-factor (physics)|''g''-factor]] in the hydrogenic ions <sup>12</sup>C<sup>5+</sup> or <sup>16</sup>O<sup>7+</sup>.
The electron relative atomic mass is an adjusted parameter in the CODATA set of fundamental physical constants, while the electron rest mass in kilograms is calculated from the values of the Planck constant, the fine structure constant and the Rydberg constant, as detailed above.<ref name="CODATA" /> <ref name="NIST" />
== Relationship to other physical constants == As mentioned above, the electron mass is used to calculate{{CN|date=June 2018}} the [[Avogadro constant]] ''N''<sub>A</sub>: :<math>N_{\rm A} = \frac{M_{\rm u} A_{\rm r}({\rm e})}{m_{\rm e}} = \frac{M_{\rm u} A_{\rm r}({\rm e})c\alpha^2}{2R_\infty h}</math> Hence it is also related to the [[atomic mass constant]] ''m''<sub>u</sub>: :<math>m_{\rm u} = \frac{N_{\rm A}}{M_{\rm u}} = \frac{A_{\rm r}({\rm e})}{m_{\rm e}} = \frac{A_{\rm r}({\rm e})c\alpha^2}{2R_\infty h}</math> where M<sub>u</sub> is [[molar mass constant]] (defined in [[SI]]) and ''A''<sub>r</sub>(e) is a directly measured quantity, the [[relative mass of electron]].
Note that ''m''<sub>u</sub> is defined in terms of ''A''<sub>r</sub>(e), and not the other way round, and so the name "electron mass in atomic mass units" for ''A''<sub>r</sub>(e) involves a circular definition (at least in terms of practical measurements).
The electron relative atomic mass also enters into the calculation of all other relative atomic masses. By convention, relative atomic masses are quoted for neutral atoms, but the actual measurements are made on positive [[ion]]s, either in a [[mass spectrometer]] or a [[Penning trap]]. Hence the mass of the electrons must be added back on to the measured values before tabulation. A correction must also be made for the mass equivalent of the [[binding energy]] ''E''<sub>b</sub>. Taking the simplest case of complete ionization of all electrons, for a nuclide X of [[atomic number]] ''Z'',<ref name="CODATA" /> :<math>A_{\rm r}({\rm X}) = A_{\rm r}({\rm X}^{Z+}) + ZA_{\rm r}({\rm e}) - E_{\rm b}/m_{\rm u}c^2\,</math> As relative atomic masses are measured as ratios of masses, the corrections must be applied to both ions: the uncertainties in the corrections are negligible, as illustrated below for hydrogen 1 and oxygen 16.
{| class="wikitable" |- !   ! <sup>1</sup>H ! <sup>16</sup>O |- | relative atomic mass of the X<sup>''Z''+</sup> ion | 1.007 276 466 77(10) | 15.990 528 174 45(18) |- | relative atomic mass of the ''Z'' electrons | 0.000 548 579 909 43(23) | 0.004 388 639 2754(18) |- | correction for the binding energy | −0.000 000 014 5985 | −0.000 002 194 1559 |- | '''relative atomic mass of the neutral atom''' | 1.007 825 032 07(10) | 15.994 914 619 57(18) |- |}
The principle can be shown by the determination of the electron relative atomic mass by Farnham ''et al.'' at the University of Washington (1995).<ref>{{citation | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.75.3598 | last1 = Farnham | first1 = D. L. | last2 = Van Dyck, Jr. | first2 = R. S. | last3 = Schwinberg | first3 = P. B. | title = Determination of the Electron's Atomic Mass and the Proton/Electron Mass Ratio via Penning Trap Mass Spectroscopy | journal = [[Physical Review Letters|Phys. Rev. Lett.]] | year = 1995 | volume = 75 | issue = 20 | pages = 3598–3601 | bibcode=1995PhRvL..75.3598F}}</ref> It involves the measurement of the frequencies of the [[cyclotron radiation]] emitted by electrons and by <sup>12</sup>C<sup>6+</sup> ions in a Penning trap. The ratio of the two frequencies is equal to six times the inverse ratio of the masses of the two particles (the heavier the particle, the lower the frequency of the cyclotron radiation; the higher the charge on the particle, the higher the frequency): :<math>\frac{\nu_c ({}^{12}{\rm C}^{6+})}{\nu_c ({\rm e})} = \frac{6A_{\rm r}({\rm e})}{A_{\rm r}({}^{12}{\rm C}^{6+})} = 0.000\,274\,365\,185\,89(58)</math> As the relative atomic mass of <sup>12</sup>C<sup>6+</sup> ions is very nearly 12, the ratio of frequencies can be used to calculate a first approximation to ''A''<sub>r</sub>(e), {{nowrap|5.486 303 7178{{e|−4}}}}. This approximate value is then used to calculate a first approximation to ''A''<sub>r</sub>(<sup>12</sup>C<sup>6+</sup>), knowing that ''E''<sub>b</sub>(<sup>12</sup>C)/''m''<sub>u</sub>''c''<sup>2</sup> (from the sum of the six ionization energies of carbon) is {{nowrap|1.105 8674{{e|−6}}}}: ''A''<sub>r</sub>(<sup>12</sup>C<sup>6+</sup>) ≈ {{nowrap|11.996 708 723 6367}}. This value is then used to calculate a new approximation to ''A''<sub>r</sub>(e), and the process repeated until the values no longer vary (given the relative uncertainty of the measurement, 2.1{{e|−9}}): this happens by the fourth cycle of iterations for these results, giving ''A''<sub>r</sub>(e) = {{nowrap|5.485 799 111(12){{e|−4}}}} for these data.
== References == {{reflist}}

The '''European Garden Heritage Network''' is a [[nonprofit organization]] established in 2003 within the EU-Programme INTERREG IIIB NWE to foster transnational co-operation in regional development and cultural heritage. It brings together garden experts, government services, foundations, and tourism agencies to preserve, develop, and promote gardens of historic interest within northwestern Europe.

{{Infobox book | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = Feminism Unmodified: Discourses on Life and Law | image = Feminismunmodified.jpg | image_size = 250px | author = [[Catharine MacKinnon]] | country = United States | language = English | subject = [[Feminism]] | publisher = [[Harvard University Press]] | release_date = 1987 | media_type = Print | pages = 332 | isbn = | oclc = | preceded_by = Sexual Harassment of Working Women: A Case of Sex Discrimination | followed_by = Pornography and Civil Rights: A New Day for Women's Equality }}
'''''Feminism Unmodified: Discourses on Life and Law''''' is a 1987 book by [[feminist]] [[academic]] [[Catharine MacKinnon]].<ref>[http://www.ou.edu/cas/psc/bookmackinnon.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100606140807/http://www.ou.edu/cas/psc/bookmackinnon.htm |date=June 6, 2010 }}</ref> The book is a collection of [[essay]]s by MacKinnon delivered during the 1980s, in which she makes a [[radical feminist]] critique of [[pornography]] and [[liberal feminism]].
==See also== *[[Ordeal (autobiography)]] *[[Andrea Dworkin]]
==References== <references/>
==Further reading== *[https://www.jstor.org/pss/3480600 Katharine T. Bartlett, Review: MacKinnon's Feminism: Power on Whose Terms?, California Law Review, Vol. 75, No. 4 (Jul., 1987), pp. 1559-1570] *[http://www.heinonline.org/HOL/Page?page=1388&handle=hein.journals%2Fmlr86&collection=journals Whitman, Christina "Law and Sex." Review of Feminism Unmodified, by C. A. MacKinnon. Mich. L. Rev. 86 (1988): 1388-403.] *[http://www.heinonline.org/HOL/Page?page=352&handle=hein.journals%2Filllr82&collection=journals Finley, Lucinda (1988) ''The Nature of Domination and the Nature of Women:Reflections on Feminism Unmodified''] *[http://heinonline.org/HOL/Page?handle=hein.journals/hlr101&id=1&size=2&collection=journals&index=journals/hlr Sustein, Cass (1988) ''Feminism and Legal Theory - Review of Feminism Unmodified] *[https://www.jstor.org/pss/1122941 Olsen, Frances (1989) 'Feminist Theory in Grand Style', Columbia Law Review, 89/5: 1147-1178] *[https://www.jstor.org/stable/4020180 Hein, Hilde (1987) ''In Search of Equality'', The Women's Review of Books, 5/1: 6-7]
==External links== *[http://www.maureenmullarkey.com/essays/porn1.html Porn in the U.S.A., Part I Hard Cop, Soft Cop: Catharine MacKinnon and Andrea Dworkin on Pornography]

[[File:Iron(II) oxide.jpg|thumb|Ferrous oxide is more correctly called [[iron(II) oxide]].]] In [[chemistry]], '''ferrous''' (Fe<sup>2+</sup>), indicates a [[divalent]] [[iron]] compound (+2 [[oxidation state]]), as opposed to [[ferric]], which indicates a [[trivalent]] iron compound (+3 oxidation state).<ref name=mw>{{Citation | title = Ferrous | url = http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ferrous | accessdate = 19 April 2008 | publisher = [[Merriam-Webster]]}}.</ref> This usage has decreased, with current [[IUPAC]] nomenclature having names containing the oxidation state in bracketed Roman numerals instead, such as [[iron(II) oxide]] for ferrous oxide (FeO), and [[iron(III) oxide]] for ferric oxide (Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>).
[[File:Pourbaix Diagram of Iron.svg|thumb|[[Pourbaix diagram]] of aqueous iron]]
Outside chemistry, ''ferrous'' indicates the presence of iron.<ref name=mw/> The word is derived from the [[Latin]] word ''{{lang|la|ferrum}}'' ("iron").<ref>{{Citation | title = Etymology (Meaning of Words) | date = 30 November 2007 | url = http://en.allexperts.com/q/Etymology-Meaning-Words-1474/Origin-word-1.htm | accessdate = 19 April 2008}}.</ref> Ferrous metals include [[steel]] and [[pig iron]] (with a carbon content of a few percent) and [[alloy]]s of iron with other metals (such as stainless steel). Manipulation of atom-to-atom relationships between iron, carbon, and various alloying elements establishes the specific properties of ferrous metals.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ferrous Alloys Properties|url=http://www.steelforge.com/literature/ferrousnon-ferrous-materials-textbook/ferrous-metals/|publisher=All Metals & Forge Group|accessdate=1 October 2013}}</ref> [[Non-ferrous]] [[metal]]s and alloys do not contain an appreciable amount of iron.<ref>{{Citation | title = Non ferrous | url = http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/non%20ferrous | accessdate = 19 April 2008 | publisher = [[Merriam-Webster]]}}.</ref>Ferric refers to iron-containing materials or compounds. In chemistry the term is reserved for iron with an oxidation number of +3, also denoted iron(III) or Fe3+. On the other hand, ferrous refers to iron with oxidation number of +2, denoted iron(II) or Fe2+.
==See also== * [[Ferromagnetism]] * [[Steelmaking]] * [[Ferrous metal recycling]] * [[Iron(II) oxide]] (ferrous oxide) * [[Iron(II) bromide]] (ferrous bromide)
==References== {{wiktionary|ferrous|nonferrous}} {{reflist}}
[[Category:Iron]]
{{chemistry-stub}}
